intro: Octopoma abruptum, commonly known as the roughleaf hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its rough, hairy leaves and showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. It typically grows in wetlands and along stream banks, thriving in moist, acidic soils. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, hard seeds.
